intro: Acaena pinnatifida var. leptophylla, commonly known as the slender-leaved burr bush, is a shrub native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its thorny stems and small, alternate leaves. The plant produces bright red, spherical fruits that contain seeds surrounded by a fibrous, burr-like structure. It thrives in coastal and subalpine environments, often growing in well-drained soils. The species is noted for its ecological importance, providing habitat and food for native wildlife.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena pinnatifida var. leptophylla is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the region of Otago. This variety grows in rocky and gravelly habitats, often in alpine or subalpine areas. It is commonly associated with dry, open environments such as hillsides and scree slopes. The plant is well adapted to the harsh climatic conditions of its native range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena pinnatifida var. leptophylla was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there by European settlers during the 19th century as part of the botanical collections. The plant is now considered an invasive species in some regions of New Zealand due to its rapid spread. It thrives in a variety of habitats, including forests and disturbed areas. Its introduction has led to ecological concerns as it outcompetes native vegetation.
